questions.neutral: Did you walk the long way?

hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah, I took the long way. Saw more patrols than usual.
Just trying to get some air after flying my drone.
Hobby gets harder every week now.
Yeah. Avoided the main road, too crowded.
I fly FPV drones for fun, keeps me sane.
Spots are trickier now, lots of sensors.
Last weekend’s patrols nearly shut down my flight.
Took the long route, especially with all the new surveillance.
I do freestyle FPV drone flying in the industrial zones.
It’s my thing, clears my head after work.
Last time, Directorate drones were everywhere — made it tense.
Still managed to fly some tricks under the containers.
Compliance checks messed up the mood a bit.
Yeah, I took the scenic route, not a fan of the cameras.
Freestyle FPV drone flying is my hobby — I need the rush.
Usually hit abandoned platforms, good signal, low interference.
Last Saturday was different: surveillance was heavy, fewer hobbyists out.
Directorate patrol drones kept passing over — even caught my frequency.
Pulled back early, didn’t want trouble.
My BCI even dipped a point after — for nothing.
Walked the long way, definitely. These days, everything feels watched or flagged.
FPV drone flying is my thing — not for delivery, just technical tricks.
Been chasing clean signal in empty industrial zones since the BCI crackdown.
Last flight, every move felt monitored; Directorate drones, banded patrols, you name it.
People used to mind their own business, now everyone is performing for the system.
I fly low-power, no logins, but picked up system pings even so.
My BCI dropped for ‘irregular routing’ just going home after. I log notes somewhere else now.
Honestly, it’s getting to where there’s no invisible corner left in the city.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still fly sometimes.
Not as much now — those new Directorate drones make it tricky.
Always checking for network pings now, can’t be too careful.
Everyone’s on their best behavior lately, even off-grid.
Flight paths get boring fast.
Still fly when I can, but things changed.
Saw more patrol drones last week near the docks.
Signals are noisier, and everyone’s watching each other.
Even the usual hobby crowd’s more cautious — mostly surface runs, no stunts.
I keep logs clean, stay low, nothing risky lately.
You never know who’s scanning.
Yeah, FPV is still my main escape.
Flying near Sector D felt emptier after all those compliance events.
Lot more drones in the sky, Directorate ones — changes your routes.
I keep Wi-Fi off, stick to analog feed for safety.
Some regulars stopped coming, guessing their BCI dipped.
Got a score drop myself after that last session — just for flying low.
Barely feels like a hobby some days.
That’s me — can’t quit flying even now.
Last Saturday’s session was tense: Directorate drones everywhere after Halden died.
Had to switch to low-power mode and hide my signal totally.
Noticed others just doing loops, nothing risky — performative flights.
Even picked up a compliance patrol on my scanner, first time ever.
Scored down one point when I got home. They’re watching for anomalies.
A few months back, we’d race or try new tricks. Now it’s just routine.
Feels like my best escape could get me flagged next.
Still my therapy, but barely feels free anymore.
Started after my little brother vanished on audit — needed the focus, you know?
Since Halden’s death, Directorate surveillance is everywhere, picked up three active pings last flight.
Most flyers faded out; a few only do ‘compliant patterns’ — showy, careful, system-friendly.
I can clean my logs, but even I got hit by a silent score drop.
Never thought I’d miss the crowd — now the whole platform’s empty.
Tracking signals is part of the play, but now it’s survival, not sport.
City’s paranoia seeps into the air itself; every move gets recorded, interpreted.
FPV used to clear my head. Lately, it just reminds me what we’ve lost.
